theme: Peripheral neuropathy due to vitamin B6 deficiency from isoniazid
questions: A 42-year-old man is being treated for pulmonary tuberculosis at a respiratory clinic in Manchester. He reports new-onset numbness and tingling in his hands and feet after several weeks of therapy. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he drinks minimal alcohol. Neurological examination reveals reduced sensation to light touch in a glove-and-stocking distribution. Which deficiency is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
notes:
Vitamin B6 deficiency is the most likely cause of this patient’s peripheral neuropathy, given the context of isoniazid therapy for tuberculosis. Isoniazid interferes with pyridoxine metabolism, leading to decreased levels of active vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate), which can result in sensory neuropathy presenting as numbness and tingling in a glove-and-stocking distribution. Prophylactic supplementation with pyridoxine is recommended during isoniazid treatment according to UK guidelines to prevent this complication.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause peripheral neuropathy, but it typically develops over a longer period and often presents with additional features such as anaemia or subacute combined degeneration of the cord (e.g., proprioceptive loss, ataxia). There is no indication from the scenario that this patient has risk factors for B12 deficiency or other neurological findings suggestive of myelopathy.

Folate deficiency may lead to megaloblastic anaemia but rarely causes isolated peripheral neuropathy. Folate-related neurological symptoms are much less common than those associated with vitamin B12 or B6 deficiencies, making it an unlikely explanation here.

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency classically results in Wernicke’s encephalopathy or beriberi—either affecting the cardiovascular system or causing more prominent motor neuropathies and central nervous system manifestations rather than isolated sensory symptoms as described here.

Vitamin E deficiency can indeed cause neurological problems including ataxia and peripheral neuropathy; however, it usually occurs in individuals with fat malabsorption syndromes or rare genetic disorders—not patients on anti-tuberculous therapy without gastrointestinal disease.

Vitamin E deficiency can indeed cause neurological problems including ataxia and peripheral neuropathy; however, it usually occurs in individuals with fat malabsorption syndromes or rare genetic disorders—not patients on anti-tuberculous therapy without gastrointestinal disease.
title: Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine)
body:
Vitamin B6 is a water soluble vitamin of the B complex group. It is converted to pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) which is a cofactor for many reactions including transamination, deamination and decarboxylation.

Causes of vitamin B6 deficiency
  • isoniazid therapy

Consequences of vitamin B6 deficiency
  • peripheral neuropathy
  • sideroblastic anemia

Diagram showing the biochemical role of vitamin B12 and vitamin B6
concept: Isoniazid therapy can cause a vitamin B6 deficiency causing peripheral neuropathy

options: Admit to hospital for ENT review and antibiotic therapy
Admit to hospital for ENT review and urgent surgical exploration
Prescribe oral antibiotics and tell her to return if bleeding hasn't resolved in 3 days
Refer to ENT for outpatient review within 2 weeks
Tell her that a small amount of bleeding up to 2 weeks after the procedure is normal
questions:
A 43-year-woman had a tonsillectomy one week ago. She presents to her GP one week later because she has noticed a small amount of blood pooling in her mouth from this morning. She believes that the blood is coming from the wound site.

The GP examines her mouth and throat and sees no other obvious source of the bleeding. A set of basic observations are all normal.

What is the most appropriate next step for the GP to take?
notes:
Admit to hospital for ENT review and antibiotic therapy is the correct answer. This patient presented with bleeding from the surgical site one week following tonsillectomy - this describes a secondary haemorrhage. All secondary post-tonsillectomy haemorrhages should be urgently reviewed by ENT. The most common cause of this is an infection of the wound site, and thus antibiotic therapy would most likely be indicated here.

Admit to hospital for ENT review and urgent surgical exploration is incorrect. This woman has presented with a secondary post-tonsillectomy haemorrhage, so she does need to be seen urgently by ENT. However, surgical intervention is typically only required in severe haemorrhages - this haemorrhage is not severe, indicated by only a small amount of blood and normal observations, and thus surgical intervention is not required.

Prescribe oral antibiotics and tell her to return if bleeding hasn't resolved in 3 days is incorrect. While antibiotics will be indicated as the haemorrhage is most likely secondary to wound infection, all post-tonsillectomy haemorrhages require ENT review.

Refer to ENT for outpatient review within 2 weeks is incorrect. Post-tonsillectomy haemorrhage requires immediate review and treatment to prevent further complications such as major haemorrhage.

Tell her that a small amount of bleeding up to 2 weeks after the procedure is normal is incorrect. This is not normal and poses a significant risk to the patient. Post-tonsillectomy haemorrhages always require immediate review by ENT and treatment.

Tell her that a small amount of bleeding up to 2 weeks after the procedure is normal is incorrect. This is not normal and poses a significant risk to the patient. Post-tonsillectomy haemorrhages always require immediate review by ENT and treatment.
title: Post-operative complications of tonsillectomy
body:
Pain

The pain may increase for up to 6 days following a tonsillectomy.

Haemorrhage

Haemorrhage is a feared complication following tonsillectomy. All post-tonsillectomy haemorrhages should be assessed by ENT.

Primary, or reactionary haemorrhage most commonly occurs in the first 6-8 hours following surgery. It is managed by immediate return to theatre.

Secondary haemorrhage occurs between 5 and 10 days after surgery and is often associated with a wound infection. Treatment is usually with admission and antibiotics. Severe bleeding may require surgery. Secondary haemorrhage occurs in around 1-2% of all tonsillectomies.
concept: Haemorrhage 5-10 days after tonsillectomy is commonly associated with a wound infection and should therefore be treated with antibiotics

6104.concept_text: Haemorrhage 5-10 days after tonsillectomy is commonly associated with a wound infection and should therefore be treated with antibiotics

questions:
A 25-year-old lady with a body mass index of 34 kg/m² comes to see you in your GP surgery. She has noticed a small right-sided breast lump. Although she states it has decreased in size over the last two weeks she is concerned about breast cancer. She denies any direct trauma but states she played rugby recently. She has no family history of breast or gynaecological cancer. Examination reveals a small, firm, poorly mobile lump in the right lower quadrant of the right breast.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Although it is important to investigate such a lump to rule out breast cancer this history described traumatic breast fat necrosis. This can occur after seemingly trivial or unnoticed injury in a woman with a raised body mass index.

Mammary duct ectasia will likely present with nipple discharge.

A palpable lymph node is likely to be tender and in the axilla.

Paget's disease presents with an eczema-like appearance of the nipple, not with a lump.

Fibroadenoma, often described as a breast mouse, is not tethered.
question:

She has no family history of breast or gynaecological cancer. Examination reveals a small, firm, poorly mobile lump in the right lower quadrant of the right breast.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Fibroadenoma, often described as a breast mouse, is not tethered.
title: Fat necrosis of the breast
body:
Fat necrosis
  • Up to 40% cases usually have a traumatic aetiology
  • Physical features usually mimic carcinoma
  • Mass may increase in size initially
concept: Traumatic breast fat necrosis can occur after unnoticed injury

questions:
A 48-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with several days of pain and redness in the left eye. There is no history of trauma. His past medical history includes rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. On examination, the left eye is visibly red and painful to palpate. The GP suspects episcleritis but sends the patient to eye casualty for further investigation. He is subsequently reviewed by an ophthalmologist who revises the diagnosis to scleritis.

What feature supports the change in diagnosis?
notes:
Episcleritis and scleritis can be difficult to distinguish clinically. If there is any suspicion of the latter, the patient should be urgently investigated as scleritis is potentially sight-threatening. Of the features listed, the biggest distinguishing factor (aside, of course, from ophthalmological examination findings) is the presence of pain. Episcleritis is typically asymptomatic or presents with a mild grittiness sensation, but scleritis usually presents with frank pain and tenderness.

Acute onset is not a clear distinguishing factor between the two conditions. Both scleritis and episcleritis present acutely.

The history of hypertension is not relevant here. Neither condition is associated with hypertension and so this is not a distinguishing factor.

The history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is not as strongly distinguishing between the two conditions as the presence of pain. Approximately 50% of scleritis cases are linked to systemic conditions, most commonly RA. However, approximately 30% of episcleritis cases are also linked to systemic conditions such as RA.

The presence of redness in itself is not a distinguishing factor, as both conditions lead to visible redness of the eye. On further examination, however, it will be noted that the vessels in episcleritis are mobile and blanch, but are immobile and do not blanch in scleritis.

title: Scleritis
body:
Scleritis describes full-thickness inflammation of the sclera. It generally has a non-infective cause and typically causes a red, painful eye.

Risk factors
  • rheumatoid arthritis: the most commonly associated condition
  • systemic lupus erythematosus
  • sarcoidosis
  • granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Features
  • 'red eye'
+ however, there may be a violet-bluish hue with scleral oedema and dilatation
  • classically painful (in comparison to episcleritis), but sometimes only mild pain/discomfort is present
  • watering and photophobia are common
  • gradual decrease in vision


Management
  • same-day assessment by an ophthalmologist
  • oral NSAIDs are typically used first-line
  • oral glucocorticoids may be used for more severe presentations
  • immunosuppressive drugs for resistant cases (and also to treat any underlying associated diseases)
concept: The presence of pain distinguishes scleritis from episcleritis

2783.concept_text: The presence of pain distinguishes scleritis from episcleritis

3292.concept_text: Scleritis is a cause of red eye that is classically painful and may be associated with reduced visual acuity and blurred vision

5489.concept_text: Consider scleritis if a patient with rheumatoid arthritis presents with a painful red eye

options: Below the subcutaneous fat, either thigh
Subdermal, left arm unless used for dialysis or previous 'non-trivial' infection
Below the subcutaneous fat, non-dominant arm
questions: A woman presents to have a Nexplanon (etonogestrel) inserted. Where is the most appropriate place to insert the implant?
notes:
The correct answer is Subdermal, non-dominant arm. Nexplanon (etonogestrel) is a subdermal contraceptive implant that should be inserted in the inner side of the non-dominant upper arm. This location allows for easy insertion and removal, while also minimising interference with daily activities. It is recommended by the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) guidelines.

The option Below the subcutaneous fat, either thigh is incorrect as this would place the implant too deep for easy removal and could potentially cause nerve or muscle damage. Additionally, this location is not recommended by any guidelines.

Subdermal, left arm unless used for dialysis or previous 'non-trivial' infection is an incorrect choice because it unnecessarily restricts the placement to one arm only. While it's true that you should avoid areas of skin with scarring or infection, there's no need to limit placement to the left arm unless there are specific contraindications such as use for dialysis.

The option Below the subcutaneous fat, non-dominant arm is incorrect since placing it below the subcutaneous fat would make it difficult to remove and could lead to complications such as nerve damage or migration of the implant.

Finally, Subdermal, buttock is not a suitable location due to potential discomfort during sitting and risk of pressure-induced migration. Furthermore, this site isn't recommended in any standard guidelines for Nexplanon insertion.

It is recommended by the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) guidelines.

Subdermal, left arm unless used for dialysis or previous 'non-trivial' infection is an incorrect choice because it unnecessarily restricts the placement to one arm only. While it's true that you should avoid areas of skin with scarring or infection, there's no need to limit placement to the left arm unless there are specific contraindications such as use for dialysis.

The option Below the subcutaneous fat, non-dominant arm is incorrect since placing it below the subcutaneous fat would make it difficult to remove and could lead to complications such as nerve damage or migration of the implant.

Finally, Subdermal, buttock is not a suitable location due to potential discomfort during sitting and risk of pressure-induced migration. Furthermore, this site isn't recommended in any standard guidelines for Nexplanon insertion.
title: Implantable contraceptives
body:
Implanon was the original non-biodegradable subdermal contraceptive implant which has been replaced by Nexplanon. From a pharmacological perspective Nexplanon is the same as Implanon. The two main differences are:
  • the applicator has been redesigned to try and prevent 'deep' insertions (i.e. subcutaneous/intramuscular)
  • it is radiopaque and therefore easier to locate if impalpable

Both versions slowly releases the progestogen hormone etonogestrel. They are typically inserted in the proximal non-dominant arm, just overlying the tricep. The main mechanism of action is preventing ovulation. They also work by thickening the cervical mucus.

Key points
  • highly effective: failure rate 0.07/100 women-years - it is the most effective form of contraception
  • long-acting: lasts 3 years
  • doesn't contain oestrogen so can be used if past history of thromboembolism, migraine etc
  • can be inserted immediately following a termination of pregnancy

Disadvantages include
  • the need for a trained professional to insert and remove device
  • additional contraceptive methods are needed for the first 7 days if not inserted on day 1 to 5 of a woman's menstrual cycle

Adverse effects
  • irregular/heavy bleeding is the main problem: this is sometimes managed using a co-prescription of the combined oral contraceptive pill. It should be remembered to do a speculum exam/STI check if the bleeding continues
  • 'progestogen effects': headache, nausea, breast pain

Interactions
  • enzyme-inducing drugs such as certain antiepileptic and rifampicin may reduce the efficacy of Nexplanon
  • the FSRH advises that women should be advised to switch to a method unaffected by enzyme-inducing drugs or to use additional contraception until 28 days after stopping the treatment

Contraindications
  • UKMEC 3*: ischaemic heart disease/stroke (for continuation, if initiation then UKMEC 2), unexplained, suspicious vaginal bleeding, past breast cancer, severe liver cirrhosis, liver cancer
  • UKMEC 4**: current breast cancer


*proven risks generally outweigh the advantages
**a condition which represents an unacceptable risk if the contraceptive method is used
links:
Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare167
Progestogen-only Implants

282.concept_text: Nexplanon - main mechanism of action is inhibition of ovulation

283.concept_text:
Contraceptives - time until effective (if not first day period):
   - instant: IUD
   - 2 days: POP
   - 7 days: COC, injection, implant, IUS

questions: A 9-year-old boy is brought to surgery with recurrent headaches. What is the most common cause of headaches in children?
notes:
The correct answer is Migraine. Migraine is the most common cause of recurrent headaches in children, accounting for approximately 60-80% of cases presenting to primary care or specialist paediatric neurology clinics. Childhood migraine typically presents with recurrent episodes of moderate to severe headache that may be bilateral (unlike the classic unilateral presentation in adults), throbbing in nature, and often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. In children, attacks are typically shorter than in adults, sometimes lasting less than 2 hours. Family history is often positive, as migraine has a strong genetic component. The prevalence of migraine increases throughout childhood, affecting approximately 3-10% of children, with a slight male predominance before puberty, after which it becomes more common in females.

Tension-type headache is the second most common cause of headaches in children, but is less common than migraine in those presenting to healthcare services. Tension-type headaches typically present as bilateral, pressing or tightening (non-pulsating) pain of mild to moderate intensity that is not aggravated by routine physical activity. These headaches are not usually associated with nausea or vomiting, though either photophobia or phonophobia (but not both) may be present. While tension-type headaches are common in the general population, children with these headaches are less likely to present to medical attention compared to those with migraine due to their typically milder nature.

Refractive errors can cause headaches in children, but they are not the most common primary cause of recurrent headaches. Uncorrected refractive errors, particularly hypermetropia (long-sightedness), can lead to eyestrain and secondary headaches, typically occurring after prolonged visual tasks such as reading or screen use. These headaches are often frontal or periorbital and worsen with visual effort. However, studies have shown that while visual problems should be considered in the differential diagnosis of recurrent headaches, they account for a relatively small proportion of primary headache disorders in children.

Depression may be associated with headaches in children, but it is not a primary cause of headaches. Rather, there is a bidirectional relationship between headaches (particularly migraine) and depression, with each condition potentially exacerbating the other. Children with chronic headaches have higher rates of depression and anxiety, and psychological factors can contribute to headache chronification. However, depression would not be considered the primary aetiology of headaches in most children presenting with this symptom.

Cluster headache is extremely rare in children, particularly before adolescence. This primary headache disorder is characterised by severe, strictly unilateral pain typically around the orbital or temporal region, lasting 15-180 minutes and occurring in clusters of frequent attacks over weeks to months. Cluster headaches are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic features such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, nasal congestion, rhinorrhoea, facial sweating, miosis, ptosis, or eyelid oedema. The prevalence of cluster headache in the paediatric population is very low, estimated at less than 0.1%, making it an unlikely cause of headaches in a 9-year-old boy.

title: Headache in children
body:
Some of the following is based on an excellent review article on the Great Ormond Street Hospital website.

Epidemiology
  • up to 50 per cent of 7-year-olds and up to 80 per cent of 15-year-old have experienced at least one headache
  • equally as common in boys/girls until puberty then strong (3:1) female preponderance

Migraine

Migraine without aura is the most common cause of primary headache in children. The International Headache Society (IHS) have produced criteria for paediatric migraine without aura:

A >= 5 attacks fulfilling features B to D
BHeadache attack lasting 4-72 hours
CHeadache has at least two of the following four features:
  • bilateral or unilateral (frontal/temporal) location
  • pulsating quality
  • moderate to severe intensity
  • aggravated by routine physical activity
DAt least one of the following accompanies headache:
  • nausea and/or vomiting
  • photophobia and phonophobia (may be inferred from behaviour)

Acute management
  • ibuprofen is thought to be more effective than paracetamol for paediatric migraine
  • triptans may be used in children >= 12 years but follow-up is required
  • sumatriptan nasal spay (licensed) is the only triptan that has proven efficacy but it is poorly tolerated by young people who don't like the taste in the back of the throat
  • it should be noted that oral triptans are not currently licensed in people < 18 years
  • side-effects of triptans include tingling, heat and heaviness/pressure sensations

Prophylaxis
  • the evidence base is limited and no clear consensus guidelines exist
  • the GOSH website states: 'in practice, pizotifen and propranolol should be used as first line preventatives in children. Second line preventatives are valproate, topiramate and amitryptiline'

Tension-type headache (TTH)

Tension-type headache is the second most common cause of headache in children. The IHS diagnostic criteria for TTH in children is reproduced below:

A At least 10 previous headache episodes fulfilling features B to D
B Headache lasting from 30 minutes to 7 days
C At least two of the following pain characteristics:
  • pressing/tightening (non/pulsating) quality
  • mild or moderate intensity (may inhibit but does not prohibit activity)
  • bilateral location
  • no aggravation by routine physical activity
D Both of the following:
  • no nausea or vomiting
  • photophobia and phonophobia, or one, but not the other is present
concept: Migraine is the most common cause of primary headache in children

508.concept_text: Migraine is the most common cause of primary headache in children

options: Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) + serum ferritin
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) + serum iron
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) + transferrin saturation
questions:
A 35-year-old man presents to the haematology clinic. He has recently been diagnosed with haemochromatosis and has been undergoing weekly venesection.

What blood tests should be performed alongside FBC to monitor his treatment?
notes:
All patients diagnosed with haemochromatosis undergoing venesection should have monitoring of their transferrin saturation and serum ferritin until these are within range. Transferrin saturation measures the amount of iron bound to a protein (transferrin) in the blood. This is the first marker to rise in haemochromatosis and levels above 45% are considered too high. Serum ferritin concentration reflects iron stores in the body and is a useful prognostic test for predicting cirrhosis risk. It is important to monitor for a complication of phlebotomy known as iron avidity. This is where patients are overtreated and have low or normal serum ferritin, with elevated transferrin saturation. This is treated with iron supplementation or monitored until serum ferritin levels return to normal.

TIBC is not monitored during haemochromatosis treatment. Hence the answer total iron-binding capacity + serum ferritin is incorrect.

Serum iron is also not monitored during haemochromatosis treatment. Hence the answer total iron-binding capacity + serum iron is incorrect.

As above, TIBC is not monitored during haemochromatosis. Hence the answer total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) + transferrin saturation is incorrect.

As above, serum iron is not monitored during haemochromatosis treatment. Hence the answer transferrin saturation + serum iron is incorrect.

Serum iron is also not monitored during haemochromatosis treatment. Hence the answer total iron-binding capacity + serum iron is incorrect.

As above, TIBC is not monitored during haemochromatosis. Hence the answer total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) + transferrin saturation is incorrect.

As above, serum iron is not monitored during haemochromatosis treatment. Hence the answer transferrin saturation + serum iron is incorrect.
title: Haemochromatosis: investigation and management
body:
Haemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder of iron absorption and metabolism resulting in iron accumulation. It is caused by the inheritance of mutations in the HFE gene on both copies of chromosome 6.

Screening for iron overload

There is continued debate about the best investigation to screen for haemochromatosis.
  • general population
    • transferrin saturation is considered the most useful marker
    • ferritin should also be measured but is not usually abnormal in the early stages of iron accumulation
  • testing family members
    • genetic testing for HFE mutation

These guidelines may change as HFE gene analysis become less expensive

Typical iron study profile in patient with haemochromatosis
  • transferrin saturation > 55% in men or > 50% in women
  • raised ferritin (e.g. > 500 ug/l) and iron
  • low TIBC

Further tests and diagnosis

Further tests
  • liver function tests
  • molecular genetic testing for the C282Y and H63D mutations
  • MRI is generally used to quantify liver and/or cardiac iron
  • liver biopsy is now generally only used if suspected hepatic cirrhosis

Management

Outline
  • venesection is the first-line treatment
    • monitoring adequacy of venesection: transferrin saturation should be kept below 50% and the serum ferritin concentration below 50 ug/l
  • desferrioxamine may be used second-line
concept: Ferritin and transferrin saturation are used to monitor treatment in haemochromatosis
links:
European Association for the Study of the Liver166
2010 Haemochromatosis guidelines

theme: Management of an inguinal hernia in a 6-week-old infant.
options: Refer for an urgent ultrasound scan
Advise conservative management until 1 year of age
questions:
A 6-week-old boy is brought to the GP. His mother has noticed an intermittent swelling in his right groin for the past week, which is more prominent when he cries. On examination, a soft, reducible, non-tender inguinal swelling is palpable. The infant is otherwise well.

Select the single most appropriate management from the options below.
notes:
Urgent referral to paediatric surgery is the correct management. This infant has a clinically obvious inguinal hernia. Inguinal hernias in infants are due to a patent processus vaginalis, which allows abdominal contents to protrude into the inguinal canal. The key factor dictating management is the patient's age. Infants, particularly those under 6 months of age, have a very high risk (up to 30%) of the hernia becoming irreducible (incarcerated) and having its blood supply compromised (strangulated). Strangulation is a surgical emergency that can lead to bowel necrosis, sepsis, and testicular infarction. Therefore, to prevent these life-threatening complications, the standard of care in the UK is to perform a herniotomy urgently, typically within days of diagnosis, even if the hernia is currently reducible and the infant is asymptomatic. An urgent referral to the on-call paediatric surgical team is mandatory.

Elective referral to paediatric surgery is incorrect. While this is the appropriate management for an uncomplicated inguinal hernia in a child over the age of one, it is not safe for an infant. The risk of incarceration and strangulation is significantly lower in older children, allowing for a planned, elective surgical repair. In a 6-week-old, the risk is unacceptably high, and waiting for a routine outpatient appointment would place the infant in significant danger. The distinction in urgency based on age is a critical concept in paediatric surgery. Delaying referral in this case would be a serious clinical error.

Reassure and review in 4 weeks would be inappropriate and dangerous. This approach might be considered for other common, self-limiting groin swellings in infancy, such as a simple hydrocele, which often resolves spontaneously. However, the history of an intermittent swelling that appears with increased intra-abdominal pressure (crying) and is reducible on examination is characteristic of an inguinal hernia, not a hydrocele. Inguinal hernias do not resolve spontaneously. Adopting a 'watch and wait' strategy would fail to address the underlying anatomical defect and expose the infant to the high risk of strangulation.

Refer for an urgent ultrasound scan is not the most appropriate next step. While ultrasound is a useful tool for evaluating groin lumps where there is diagnostic uncertainty, it is not required in this case. The clinical history and examination findings are pathognomonic for a reducible inguinal hernia. Requesting an ultrasound would introduce an unnecessary delay to definitive management. The priority for this 6-week-old infant is prompt surgical assessment to mitigate the high risk of incarceration. The clinical diagnosis is sufficient to warrant an immediate referral to paediatric surgery.

Advise conservative management until 1 year of age is incorrect. This advice is sometimes given for umbilical hernias, as the fascial defect at the umbilicus often closes spontaneously during the first few years of life. However, this pathophysiology does not apply to inguinal hernias. The patent processus vaginalis that causes an inguinal hernia will not close on its own. Therefore, all inguinal hernias require surgical correction. For an infant, this correction must be performed urgently due to the high risk of life-threatening complications.

title: Paediatric inguinal hernia
body:
Inguinal hernias are a common disorder in children. They are commoner in males as the testis migrates from its location on the posterior abdominal wall, down through the inguinal canal. A patent processus vaginalis may persist and be the site of subsequent hernia development.

Children presenting in the first few months of life are at the highest risk of strangulation and the hernia should be repaired urgently. Children over 1 year of age are at lower risk and surgery may be performed electively. For paediatric hernias a herniotomy without implantation of mesh is sufficient. Most cases are performed as day cases, neonates and premature infants are kept in hospital overnight as there is a recognised increased risk of post operative apnoea.
concept: Inguinal hernia in infants = Urgent surgery

options: Analgesia and come back in 5 days for review
questions:
A 7-year-old male presents to his general practitioner accompanied by his mother. He has been suffering from a severe sore throat for the last three days. His temperature reached 39.5ºC last night so the mother decided to bring him in today.

He denies any cough or earache and was a previously healthy child, with no allergies. On examination, the doctor notices evident cervical lymphadenopathy and enlarged tonsils, but no tonsillar exudate.

Which one of the following management plans is the most appropriate?
notes:
The correct answer is phenoxymethylpenicillin for 10 days. This child is presenting with the classic signs and symptoms of acute tonsillitis: fever, sore throat and cervical lymphadenopathy. He is scoring 3 out of 4 on the Centor criteria (+1 for fever, +1 for the absence of cough and +1 for anterior cervical lymphadenopathy). This score indicates that the infection is likely to be bacterial rather than viral, requiring antibiotics. Hence, the first-line antibiotic to prescribe is phenoxymethylpenicillin. Antibiotics are of vital importance in acute bacterial tonsillitis, as it could develop into quinsy, a potentially deadly complication.

Analgesia and abundant fluid administration are suggested in cases of mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus). The classic triad of sore throat, pyrexia and lymphadenopathy is seen in around 98% of cases of mononucleosis, but in this case, the patient also has enlarged tonsils. Additionally, mononucleosis is most commonly found in adolescents and not children, making this diagnosis and management unlikely.

Amoxicillin for 5 days is prescribed in cases of otitis media. The most defining characteristic of otitis media is otalgia, which is absent in this patient making this diagnosis and management unlikely.

Analgesia and come back in 5 days for review is an incorrect answer. Antibiotic treatment should be given immediately if the patient is scoring 3 or more on the Centor criteria. If not given in bacterial tonsillitis, it can develop into a dangerous peritonsillar abscess.

Erythromycin for 10 days is wrong since this antibiotic is used as a second-line treatment in cases where phenoxymethylpenicillin cannot be used. In this case, there are no contraindications for the usage of the first-line treatment.

title: Sore throat
body:
Sore throat encompasses pharyngitis, tonsillitis, and laryngitis.

The diagnosis is clinical: throat swabs and rapid antigen tests should not be carried out routinely in patients with a sore throat

Management
  • paracetamol or ibuprofen for pain relief
  • antibiotics are not routinely indicated
  • there is some evidence that a single dose of oral corticosteroid may reduce the severity and duration of pain, although this has not yet been incorporated into UK guidelines

NICE indications for antibiotics
  • features of marked systemic upset secondary to the acute sore throat
  • unilateral peritonsillitis
  • a history of rheumatic fever
  • an increased risk from acute infection (such as a child with diabetes mellitus or immunodeficiency)
  • patients with acute sore throat/acute pharyngitis/acute tonsillitis when 3 or more Centor criteria are present

Scoring systems

The Centor criteria are: score 1 point for each (maximum score of 4)
  • presence of tonsillar exudate
  • tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy or lymphadenitis
  • history of fever
  • absence of cough

Centor scoreLikelihood of isolating Streptococci
0 or 1 or 23 to 17%
3 or 432 to 56%

The FeverPAIN criteria are: score 1 point for each (maximum score of 5)
  • Fever over 38°C.
  • Purulence (pharyngeal/tonsillar exudate).
  • Attend rapidly (3 days or less)
  • Severely Inflamed tonsils
  • No cough or coryza

FeverPAIN scoreLikelihood of isolating Streptococci
0 or 113 to 18%
2 or 334% to 40%
4 or 562% to 65%

If antibiotics are indicated then either phenoxymethylpenicillin or clarithromycin (if the patient is penicillin-allergic) should be given.
concept: Phenoxymethylpenicillin is the first line antibiotic for tonsillitis
media:
Understanding Tonsillitis
Zero To Finals - YouTube152

1851.concept_text: Phenoxymethylpenicillin is the first line antibiotic for tonsillitis

questions:
A 21-year-old female with a history of cystic fibrosis is admitted to the emergency department with a fever and a productive cough. On examination, she has a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, a pulse rate of 121 beats per minute and saturations of 93% on air. She has coarse crackles at the base of the left lung and generalised patchy wheezing. A chest x-ray is performed which shows the following:

Chest X-rayThere is a patchy opacity at the left base with minor blunting of the left costophrenic angle. The trachea is central and the right lung field is broadly clear. Enlarged airways are visible in both lung fields with some fluid levels.

Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical condition?
notes:
Patients with cystic fibrosis develop bronchiectasis early on during their life resulting in repeated hospital admissions with lower respiratory tract infections. The pathological process behind bronchiectasis results in sputum pooling within the larger airways with poor removal. Subsequently colonisation occurs with bacteria and occasionally fungi. The most common bacteria is the gram negative rod Pseudomonas aeruginosa and should always be taken into account if providing empirical treatment. If the patient is systemically well then antibiotic sensitivities should be sought from a culture sample before starting treatment. However, an anti-pseudomonal agent such as piperacillin with tazobactam or ciprofloxacin should be used as part of empirical treatment for sepsis in cystic fibrosis patients.

While Staphylococcus aureus is one of the most common pathogens in general, within the cystic fibrosis population it is significantly less common and is more associated with pre-existing influenza infection. Haemophilus pneumoniae is an important pathogen in cystic fibrosis but not as common as Pseudomonas. Haemophilus is also the most common pathogen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although Legionella more commonly causes infections in patients with cystic fibrosis than in the general population, it is not as common as Pseudomonas. Infection with Klebsiella is rare and most often associated with malnourished alcoholics rather than cystic fibrosis.

title: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
body:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an aerobic Gram-negative rod. It causes a number of clinically important infections in humans:
  • chest infections (especially in cystic fibrosis)
  • skin: burns, wound infections, 'hot tub' folliculitis
  • otitis externa (especially in diabetics who may develop malignant otitis externa)
  • urinary tract infections

Lab features
  • Gram-negative rod
  • non-lactose fermenting
  • oxidase positive

Pathophysiology
  • produces both an endotoxin (causes fever and shock) and exotoxin A (inhibits protein synthesis by catalyzing ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor EF-2)
concept: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an important organism causing LRTI in cystic fibrosis patients
media:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Osmosis - YouTube00

9460.concept_text: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an important organism causing LRTI in cystic fibrosis patients
